title: India wants better price and security: why Tapi may not reach its destination
text:
Supply via the Tapi pipeline could fulfil 30%-35% of India’s gas requirements. But the country finds the landed price of Turkmen gas at USD10 per mmBtu too high. Also, concern over Pakistan cutting supply in case of a conflict is holding back India from going full throttle on the project. The alternative: US gas.

Yet nothing went to plan. Three years after the four participating nations signed an initial investment agreement to turn the Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India (Tapi) gas pipeline into reality, the chances could help India run its gas-based power plants and address electricity deficit, which has touched 8,000MW, according to Michael Kugelman, a senior associate for south and south-east Asia at the Wilson Center, a Washington DC-based think tank.
